ai-dn26:2.1_0: Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a king named Daḷhanemi who was a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extended to all four sides, he achieved stability in the country, and he possessed the seven treasures.
ai-dn26:2.2_0: He had the following seven treasures:
ai-dn26:2.3_0: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the treasurer, and the counselor as the seventh treasure.
ai-dn26:2.4_0: He had over a thousand sons who were valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.
ai-dn26:2.5_0: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigned by principle, without rod or sword.
ai-dn26:3.1_0: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, King Daḷhanemi addressed one of his men,
ai-dn26:3.2_0: ‘My good man, when you see that the heavenly wheel-treasure has receded back from its place, please tell me.’
ai-dn26:3.4_0: After many thousand years had passed, that man saw that the heavenly wheel-treasure had recededed back from its place. So he went to King Daḷhanemi and sat down on the spot.
ai-dn26:3.4_1: and after going, he said this to the King:
ai-dn26:3.5_0: ‘Please sire, you should know that your heavenly wheel-treasure has receded back from its place.’
ai-dn26:3.6_0: So the king summoned the crown prince and said,

ai-dn26:3.12_0: I shall shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
ai-dn26:3.13_0: And so, after carefully instructing the crown prince in kingship, King Daḷhanemi shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-dn26:3.14_0: Seven days later the heavenly wheel-treasure vanished.

ai-dn26:4.4_0: He went to the royal sage and said,
ai-dn26:4.5_0: ‘Please sire, you should know that the heavenly wheel-treasure has vanished.’
ai-dn26:4.6_0: When he said this, the royal sage said to him,
ai-dn26:4.7_0: ‘Don’t be unhappy at the vanishing of the wheel-treasure. My dear, the wheel-treasure is not inherited from your father.
ai-dn26:4.8_0: Come now, my dear, implement the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch.
ai-dn26:4.9_0: If you do so, it’s possible that—on a fifteenth day sabbath, having bathed your head and gone upstairs in the royal longhouse to observe the sabbath—the heavenly wheel-treasure will appear to you, with a thousand spokes, with rim and hub, complete in every detail.’
ai-dn26:5.1_0: ‘But what, sir, is that noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch?’
ai-dn26:5.2_0: ‘Well then, my dear, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as your flag, banner, and authority—provide just protection and security for your court, troops, aristocrats, vassals, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.
ai-dn26:5.3_0: Do not let injustice prevail in the realm.
ai-dn26:5.4_0: Pay money to the penniless in the realm.
ai-dn26:5.5_0: And there are ascetics and brahmins in the realm who avoid intoxication and negligence, are settled in patience and gentleness, and who tame, calm, and extinguish themselves. From time to time you should go up to them and ask:
ai-dn26:5.6_0: “Sirs, what is skillful? What is unskillful? What is blameworthy? What is blameless? What should be cultivated? What should not be cultivated? Doing what leads to my lasting harm and suffering? Doing what leads to my lasting welfare and happiness?”
ai-dn26:5.7_0: Having heard them, you should reject what is unskillful and undertake and follow what is skillful.
ai-dn26:5.8_0: These are the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch.’
ai-dn26:5.10_0: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the new king to the royal sage. And he implemented the noble duties of a wheel-turning monarch.

ai-dn26:26.2_0: After staying there, he will give it away to ascetics and brahmins, paupers, vagrants, travelers, and beggars. Then, having shaved off his hair and beard and dressed in ocher robes, he will go forth from the lay life to homelessness in the Buddha Metteyya’s presence.
ai-dn26:26.3_0: Soon after going forth, living withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, he will realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He will live having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-dn26:27.1_0: Mendicants, be your own island, your own refuge, with no other refuge. Let the teaching be your island and your refuge, with no other refuge.
ai-dn26:27.2_0: And how does a mendicant do this?
ai-dn26:27.3_0: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-dn26:27.5_0: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind ...
ai-dn26:27.6_0: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
ai-dn26:27.7_0: That’s how a mendicant is their own island, their own refuge, with no other refuge. That’s how they let the teaching be their island and their refuge, with no other refuge.
ai-dn26:28.0_0: On Long Life and Beauty for Mendicants
ai-dn26:28.1_0: Mendicants, you should roam inside your own territory, the domain of your fathers.
ai-dn26:28.2_0: Doing so, you will grow in life span, beauty, happiness, wealth, and power.
ai-dn26:28.3_0: And what is long life for a mendicant?
ai-dn26:28.4_0: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.
ai-dn26:28.5_0: the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort ...
ai-dn26:28.6_0: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort.
ai-dn26:28.7_0: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort.
ai-dn26:28.8_0: Having developed and cultivated these four bases of psychic power they may, if they wish, live on for the eon or what’s left of the eon.
ai-dn26:28.9_0: This is long life for a mendicant.
ai-dn26:28.10_0: And what is beauty for a mendicant?
ai-dn26:28.11_0: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and seeking alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
ai-dn26:28.12_0: This is beauty for a mendicant.
ai-dn26:28.13_0: And what is happiness for a mendicant?
ai-dn26:28.14_0: Now, take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
ai-dn26:28.17_0: dwells having attained the fourth absorption.
ai-dn26:28.18_0: This is happiness for a mendicant.
ai-dn26:28.19_0: And what is wealth for a mendicant?
ai-dn26:28.20_0: Firstly, a monk meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
ai-dn26:28.20_1: third (direction) in the same way as the third (direction)),
ai-dn26:28.20_3: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-dn26:28.23_0: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth.
ai-dn26:28.23_2: third (direction) in the same way as the third (direction)),
ai-dn26:28.23_4: In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
ai-dn26:28.24_0: This is wealth for a mendicant.
ai-dn26:28.25_0: And what is power for a mendicant?
ai-dn26:28.26_0: It’s when a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-dn26:28.27_0: This is power for a mendicant.
ai-dn26:28.28_0: Mendicants, I do not see a single power so hard to defeat as the power of Māra.
ai-dn26:28.29_0: It is due to undertaking skillful qualities that this merit grows.”
ai-dn26:28.30_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-dn26:28.31_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-dn26:28.32_0: The third chapter on the wheel-turning monarch is finished.
